overview: Leh is the high‑altitude capital of Ladakh, situated in the Indus River Valley at the crossroads of historic trade routes. The town is compact, with a narrow‑laned old quarter, a bustling Main Bazaar and the nearby agricultural suburb of Changspa. It serves as a gateway for trekking and cultural tours, but visitors must acclimatise to the altitude (≈3,555 m).
bestTimeToVisit: May to September (summer months when roads are open and services are fully available)
idealDuration: 3–4 days to explore the town, its bazaar, Changspa and nearby cultural sites
approximateDailyBudgetINR: ₹1,500–₹2,500 per day (including budget guesthouse, meals and local transport)
travelTips: Acclimatise slowly; avoid strenuous activity on the first two days to reduce altitude‑sickness risk
Winter (December‑February) is very cold and many hotels, shops and trekking operators close; verify arrangements in advance
Book long‑distance bus or taxi tickets at least a day ahead, especially for Srinagar‑Leh and Manali‑Leh routes
Local buses are crowded and have no ticket office; arrive early and pay the conductor directly
Public buses to nearby villages cost as little as ₹20; keep change handy
Motorbike rentals are available locally but ensure the bike is suitable for high‑altitude travel and you have proper insurance
Fixed‑price taxis can be hired from the Fort Road stand; a fare booklet costs ₹20
Carry a small cash reserve (₹200–₹300) for roadside rest‑stop meals or emergency needs
